Financial Comments: Bid award in the amount of $439,698.22. Funded by the Water Fund.
Award bid for the 2014 Water System Project to Sharpe & Preszler Construction, Inc.
One of the focus areas of the water system capital improvement program is addressing high priority failing water systems that do not qualify as IRRP eligible
projects. This project is a combination of projects identified in the Council adopted 2013 6-year Water System Master plan (projects DS-6, 10, 27 and 32).
Additionally, the following are policy goals identified in the City's Comprehensive Plan that further support this action:
UT Policy 1. Maintenance and rehabilitation of the City’s utility infrastructure is of paramount importance and should be adequately funded (Goal 7, Objective
UT Policy 6. All public or private water systems should be monitored and regularly maintained (Goal 6, Objective 4)
UT Policy 14. Public facilities should be developed, improved and maintained according to high standards of design and performance, to serve as examples
The 2014 Water System Project will occur on Wauna Vista Drive, Home Avenue, Crestline Drive and a portion of Brevor Drive. Failing water main will be
replaced as a continuation of last year’s Brevor Drive project in the Stubblefield Subdivision. Within the project limits, the water system has had 16 (recorded)
leak repairs in the past 10 years. The steel water mains are over 49 years old and were installed without bedding in alkaline soils, which accelerated the
On February 26, 2014, the City published a call for competitive bids for the 2014 Water System Project. Eight plan
sets were purchased by potential bidders. On March 19, 2014, seven bids were opened. The Engineer's estimate for
the project was $523,915. The low bidder was Sharpe & Preszler Construction Co., Inc., of Kennewick, Washington,
with a bid in the amount of $439,698.23. Staff has reviewed the contractor's qualifications and found them to be
qualified and their bid to be fair and reasonable.
This award will be financed through the Water Fund revenue that is supported by utility rates that were approved by
Council action at the April 14, 2010, Council meeting. The construction bid of $439,698.23 is within the construction
Council may award the bid or direct staff to prepare a resolution rejecting all bids and re-bid the project at a later
Staff recommends that Council approve the resolution awarding the bid for the 2014 Water System Project, and
authorizing the City Manager to execute the construction contract with Sharpe & Preszler Construction Co., Inc., of
A RESOLUTION AWARDING THE BID FOR THE 2014 WATER SYSTEM PROJECT
AND TAKING SUCH FURTHER ACTION NEEDED THEREWITH
WHEREAS, the City of Walla Walla passed Municipal Ordinance A-2405 on May
13, 1970 which classified the City of Walla Walla as a nonchartered code city under Title
35A of the Revised Code Washington (RCW); and
WHEREAS, RCW 35A.40.210(1) provides in pertinent part that “[p]rocedures for
any public work or improvement contracts or purchases for code cities shall be governed
by the following statutes, as indicated: ... For code cities of twenty thousand population or
WHEREAS, RCW 35.22.620(3) provides in pertinent part that competitive public
bids are required for certain projects; and
WHEREAS, the City of Walla Walla published and advertised a call for
competitive bids for replacement of its 2014 water system project on February 26, 2014;
WHEREAS, all timely bid proposals have been evaluated and Sharp & Preszler
Construction Co, Inc. is the lowest responsible bidder, and
WHEREAS, the Walla Walla City Council has considered this matter during a
regularly and duly called public meeting of said Council, has given said matter careful
review and consideration, and finds that good government and the best interests of the City
of Walla Walla will be served by passage of this resolution;

text.b: NOW THEREFORE, the City Council of the City of Walla Walla do resolve

page.text: The contract for the 2014 water system project is hereby awarded to Sharp
& Preszler Construction Co, Inc., and the City Manager of the City of Walla Walla is
hereby authorized, empowered and directed to execute said contract behalf of the City of

George Bell, Public Works Department, Streets
Financial Comments: Not to exceed $209,414.70 including tax
Award the bid to A & B Asphalt, Inc. for purchase of hot mix asphalt for use by the City's Street Division for 2014.
A Request for Bids was prepared and advertised in the Union Bulletin on March 23. Bids were opened on April 1,
2014, at the office of the City Clerk. The City received two bids. Staff has reviewed the bids and determined that A &
B Asphalt, Inc. provided the lowest responsive bid.
The quantities listed in the request for bids are approximate estimates of the quantities needed for the year.
This material will be used by the Street Division for the purposes of utility patching, pot-hole filling, street repairs and
the planned 2014 overlay projects outlined on "GoWallaWalla.us."
The 2014 budget currently has $260,000 for purchase of hot mix asphalt.
Reject all bids and issue a new request for bids.
Adopt the resolution awarding the bid of hot mix asphalt to A & B Asphalt, Inc. in the amount of $209,414.70 including
per ton for class 1/2 inch and $64.10 per ton for class 3/8 inch).
Approved for City Council action. Let's pave more streets!

The City of Walla Walla is seeking bids for hot mix asphalt. Bids are due by 1:00 p.m. on April 1, 2014, and
are to be submitted to the City Clerk’s office, 15 N. 3
Bids shall be in a sealed envelope and marked “2014 Hot Mix Asphalt Bid.”
A complete bidder’s packet may be obtained by visiting the City’s website at

text.b: CALL FOR BIDS FOR HOT MIX ASPHALT

page.text: The following “Instructions to Bidders,” “Specifications,” and “Bid Proposal” are for materials to be used
by the City of Walla Walla Public Works Department.
The venue and jurisdiction of any actions of claim for or against the bidder or the City of Walla Walla
Public Works Department shall be in Walla Walla County and in the District Court or Superior Courts
thereof according to the jurisdictional amount.
These instructions to bidders are a part of the specifications.
The City must be notified by 3:00 p.m. on Thursday, March 27, 2014, of any revisions the bidder
suggests be made to the detailed specifications. Any changes, additions or deletions to the
specifications by the City will be made by written addendum only and will be posted on the
City’s website under “bids and RFPs”. Prior to submitting bids, all bidders shall check the City’s
website after 10:00 a.m. on Monday, March 31, 2014, to confirm receipt of all addenda.
Bids will be considered final at the time and date stated for opening bids. The City will not
accept any changes for any reason.
Use of the enclosed bid proposal is required. Only bids submitted on the official bid proposal
Washington State Sales Tax WILL NOT be considered a part of the total bid. The successful
bidder shall protect, defend, indemnify and hold the City, its agents, employees, officials and
officers harmless from any damages, costs, or liability for any injuries to persons or property
arising from acts or omissions of the bidder, bidder’s employees, agents or subcontractors,
The bidder shall not discriminate against any client, employee, or applicant for employment and
services on the grounds of race, creed, color, national origin, sex, marital status, age or presence
of any sensory, mental, or physical handicap unless based upon a bona fide occupational
The bid shall be placed in a SEALED ENVELOPE marked on the outside "2014 HOT MIX ASPHALT
BID” and may be mailed or hand delivered to the City of Walla Walla City Clerk’s Office, 15 N.

text.b: Avenue, Walla Walla, Washington 99362. All bids must be received at the above location

page.text: The City of Walla Walla reserves the right to accept or reject any or all bids submitted. The City
reserves the right to waive any irregularity in the bids to accept in whole or in part such bid or
bids as may be deemed in the best interest of the City.
Any additional information or questions concerning this call for Bids can be obtained by emailing
Firm bids are requested for Hot Mix Asphalt for the period April 14, 2014, through November
30, 2014. The estimated quantity is 3,000 tons. 1,500 tons each of Class 1/2 and 3/8 inch Hot
Mix Asphalt recycled asphalt pavement (RAP) permitted per WSDOT Specifications.
Bidders shall submit their bids on the official City bid proposal form, included herein.
Supplemental information can be provided on your own letterhead, but only bids submitted on
the official form will be considered.
Receipt of product will be made on an "as needed - when needed" basis. Daily quantities may be
as little as 2 tons of product or as much as 150 tons of product. Payment will only be for
quantity of material purchased. The estimated quantity is for bidding purposes only.
The bid price for both classes of hot mix asphalt shall be FOB at the plant. The supplier shall
load the asphalt into City trucks. The successful bidder shall have operators available at the
plant to load City trucks by 7:30 a.m. until 3:30 p.m. each work day. The supplier shall reimburse
the City for labor and equipment expenses associated with delays due to:
a) operator not being available to load trucks during this time period;
c) loading delays in excess of ½ hour after City trucks arrive at the plant.
The supplier may be assessed standby charges for crew costs up to $1,000 per hour for such
delays to cover actual labor and equipment costs until crews can be reassigned to other
projects. To help preclude such impacts, a City representative will contact the designated plant
representative by 6:30 a.m. to alert supplier of City’s plans to pick up hot mix. Should problems
arise which cause mix to be unavailable, the supplier must notify the City Street Division (phone:
509-527-4363) by 7:00 a.m. on the day mix is needed to enable the City to reassign crews to
alternative projects. Failure to do so will result in downtime for City forces and financial
assessment for the delay. In the event of two or more such delays, the City may, at its
discretion, declare the supplier to be in default and proceed with purchasing material from
The primary asphalt plant must be located within 15 miles of Walla Walla. The City reserves the
right to obtain asphalt from any plants the company operates at other locations for the same
Hot mix asphalt shall meet the requirements of the 2014 Edition, WSDOT standard specification
for HMA CL ½” PG 64-28 and HMA CL 3/8” PG 64-28 (as modified herein). The minimum asphalt
binder content shall be 5.5%. A WSDOT approved anti-strip additive will be required at the rate
of .5%, unless a WSDOT approved mix design is presented, with a different determination of
anti-strip requirements. Anti-strip additives shall be added to the asphalt binder prior to
shipment to the contractor. Documentation shall be provided to the City.
Section 9.03.8(6) WSDOT Standard Specifications Proportions of Materials
Aggregate Gradation Control Points for 3/8” are modified as follows:
Asphalt Cost Price Adjustment: The City of Walla Walla may make an Asphalt Cost Price
Adjustment, either credit or a payment, for qualifying changes in the reference cost of asphalt
binder. The adjustment is not a guarantee of full compensation for changes in the cost of asphalt
binder. The City of Walla Walla does not guarantee that asphalt binder will be available at the
reference cost. The asphalt binder reference cost is updated based on information in the
Washington State Department of Transportation (WSDOT) website at:
The reference cost will be determined using posted prices furnished by Poten & Partners, Inc.
The base cost established for this contract is the reference cost posted on the WSDOT website
for the period immediately preceding the bid opening date.
Adjustments will be based on the reference cost for Eastern Washington as posted on the
of each month. The adjustment will be calculated as follows:
No adjustment will be made if the reference cost is within 5% of the base cost.
If the reference cost is greater than or equal to 105% of the base cost, then
Adjustment = (Current Reference Cost – (1.05 x Base Cost)) x (Q x 0.056).
If the reference cost is less than or equal to 95% of the base cost, then
Adjustment = (Current Reference Cost – (0.95 x Base Cost)) x (Q x 0.056).
Q = total tons of HMA paid in the current month’s progress payment.
Contractor’s invoices shall clearly reflect binder reference cost used in calculating requested
Workability of the AC material supplied is an important factor the City will use as acceptance
criteria. In regards specifically to the 3/8” material, the intended use is for skin patching, leveling
up, and small miscellaneous patch work. The ½ material’s intended use is for utility patching at
depths of 3” typically. The material must meet the specifications herein and be workable for the
Unless specified otherwise, all materials shall meet the requirements of the latest Edition of the
WSDOT Standard Specifications. The tolerances for Commercial Evaluation [WSDOT Standard
Specification 5-04.3(7)A3] will be used for acceptance. The City will select a certified laboratory
for performing tests and will take samples for testing. Should the Hot Mix Asphalt fail to meet
specifications, the City will reserve the right to make equitable price adjustments, including
possibly not paying for the mix. Costs incurred by the City in performing tests on non-
specification compliant material shall be deducted from monies owed to the supplier.
Acceptance of the asphalt will be based upon laboratory tests and visual acceptance of the mix
by the City. Tests performed and frequency will be at the discretion of the City.
Material found to be out of specification may be cause for the City to declare the supplier to be
in default and proceed with purchasing material from other sources. Said declaration will be at
the sole discretion of the City.
Contaminated or unsuitable asphalt will be returned to the supplier at no cost to the City of
Walla Walla. Supplier will also be subject to costs borne by the City related to time loss/returned
The following is required, in order to meet accounting practices and to expedite payment:
a) Submit invoices no later than 30 days subsequent to delivery of services.
b) Invoices and statements must include accurate pricing, quantity, detail of costs, and
c) If needed, correction invoices must be provided to the City within 10 business days of
d) No duplicate, triplicate, etc. invoices for the same charge(s).
e) Credit invoices for actual credits only. Upon receipt of a credit invoice the City will
assume that a credit is due and therefore will not pay the charges from another invoice.
f) Contractor will be subject to hourly charges for City time spent in addressing/correcting
any of the above or related matters.
The following items must be completed in full by the bidder to submit a valid bid.
[ ] 3. Affirmation of receipt of addenda on the Bid Proposal.
[ ] 4. Place all above items in properly marked and SEALED ENVELOPE.
Kammy Hill, City Clerk, City of Walla Walla

Frank Nicholson, Public Works Department, Engineering
Financial Comments: This contract amendment is for $62,210. Project funding will come from the wastewater
Amendment #1 with Anderson Perry and Associates for design and construction phase services on the Palouse
Street to First Avenue Sewer Replacement Project for $62,210.
The sewer line located between Alder Street and Mill Creek, from First Avenue to Palouse Street is in critical need of
replacement. Defects to the line necessitated that planning work begin immediately for the project. This sewer line
runs underneath the City's Alder Street parking lot (behind Macy's), through the alleys to the east, and across
Palouse Street. The line's path passes very near to several downtown buildings, threatening to cause significant
construction impacts if the replacement is accomplished by a conventional open trench method.
On February 24, 2014, the City signed a contract to begin preliminary design/planning work immediately on the
project, which included a feasibility analysis for pipe bursting. Anderson Perry and Associates was chosen as the most
qualified firm from the Professional Services Roster to plan the sewer line replacement project. Their expertise,
combined with their knowledge of the adjacent Alder Street Improvement project and neighboring property and
business owners made them the logical choice. They will be best able to plan both projects to minimize construction
impacts to area merchants and the traveling public. This contract amendment (#1) is for the full final design, bidding
and construction inspection of the project.
The original contract signed in February was for $19,510. This amendment is $62,210 for a new total contract price of
$81,720. Funding will be provided by the Wastewater fund.
The City could conduct an RFP process to look for a different consultant. However, an RFP process would delay the project.
Adopt a resolution awarding the professional services contract amendment, and authorizing the City Manager to
execute said amendment on behalf of the City of Walla Walla with Anderson Perry & Associates, Inc for professional
services in the amount of $62,210.00 for the sewer pipe bursting project.

text.b: FINAL DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION ADMINISTRATION SERVICES
PALOUSE STREET TO 1ST AVENUE – ALLEY SEWER REPLACEMENT

page.text: This project generally includes the tasks required to complete the design and provide construction
administration services for the City of Walla Walla's (CITY) Palouse Street to 1st Avenue – Alley Sewer
Replacement Project. Specific work elements authorized as part of this agreement include utility
coordination, pipe bursting design, preparing construction plans and specifications, bidding and award
assistance, construction administration and inspection services, and project closeout.
In general, the design and construction administration services will include, but not be limited to, the
75 Percent Design Submittal with Specifications and Cost Estimate
Complete Final Plans, Specifications, and Estimate (PS&E) for the project
Review and Approval of Material Submittals
Tracking and Issuance of Weekly Statements of Working Days
Review Contractor Monthly Pay Estimates and Submit to the CITY
Review Contractor Proposals for Alternate "Or Equal" Materials
Schedule and Attend Weekly On‐Site Construction Meetings
Coordinate/Communicate with Adjacent Property Owners/Residents As Needed
Prepare and Submit Construction Record Drawings
Supplemental If Requested – Provide Coordination and Personnel for Geotechnical Inspections,
Archaeological Services, or other Services Requested by the CITY
S:\DOCS\WW CITY\359‐135 ALLEY SEWER REPLACEMENT\AGREEMENT\AMENDMENT\EXHIBIT 1 ‐ SCOPE OF WORK.docx

text.b: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF ANDERSON PERRY & ASSOCIATES, INC. (CONSULTANT)

page.text: The CONSULTANT will oversee project tasks and coordinate with CITY representatives to manage the
scope, schedule, and budget for the engineering services.

text.b: Contract Administration, Invoicing, and Progress Reports

page.text: 1. Prepare and submit monthly invoices. Each invoice will include: Date period covered by the
invoice, the number of hours worked during the billing period with billing rates shown,
expenses and associated markups, the total cost for labor and expenses for the billing
period, subconsultant fees including markups for the billing period, and a total amount
summarizing labor, expenses, and subconsultant fees.
2. Prepare a Contract Summary Report to accompany the monthly invoices. This report will list
each invoice, including the current invoice, with an itemized summary of invoice numbers,
dates, and amounts billed for labor, expenses, and subconsultants as well as the total
amounts for each invoice. The Contract Summary Report will also list the total amount billed
to date, the total amount remaining under the contract, and the contract expiration date.
3. Prepare a brief Project Status Report to accompany the monthly invoices. This report will
include: Date period covered by the report, a brief summary of the work performed during
the billing period, a notice to the CITY raising any issues or concerns that could require a
contract amendment/supplement, a brief summary of completed and/or upcoming project
milestones, and any CITY action items needed for project delivery. The CONSULTANT will
monitor the budget status and take actions to correct undesirable budget trends involving
the CITY if the scope is impacted.
4. Prepare the project design schedule. The schedule shall identify CONSULTANT tasks and
items provided by the CITY and other consultants. The schedule shall be updated as
circumstances require, or as requested by the CITY.
5. Project Management. General coordination with the CITY, subconsultants, other
consultants, and stakeholders as well as ongoing monitoring of tasks and resources.
6. Maintain all contract‐required documentation. Provide copies of project files and records to
the CITY for audits and public information requests. All final documents shall be provided in
□ Monthly Invoices, Contract Summary Reports, and Project Status Reports
S:\DOCS\WW CITY\359‐135 ALLEY SEWER REPLACEMENT\AGREEMENT\AMENDMENT\EXHIBIT 1 ‐ SCOPE OF WORK.docx
Various meetings will likely require the CONSULTANT to prepare information, participate, and
document outcomes. The anticipated meetings are as follows:
1. Project kickoff meeting with CITY staff and others to be determined in consultation with the
CITY. The purpose of the meeting shall be to review and modify the draft project
2. Project meetings to discuss and resolve project issues as they arise. Depending on the
agenda, these meetings will likely be a combination of phone conference calls and in‐person
The CONSULTANT will research and identify existing utilities in the project area that may be
affected and contact utilities to verify location data. Based on these utility reviews, the
CONSULTANT will update utility information in the survey base map if necessary. The
CONSULTANT will work with the CITY and utility provider to coordinate any required utility
relocations and will document all utility coordination efforts.
The CITY will provide the CONSULTANT with utility plans, GIS, and other supporting
documents for CITY utilities potentially affected by this project.
Utility design location fees are not included in the CONSULTANT's costs and will be paid by
See attached Exhibit 3 prepared by Staheli Trenchless Consultants. Tasks 4 through 9 of their
The CONSULTANT will develop construction phasing sequences and traffic control plans to
accommodate the project while minimizing impacts to area businesses. The CONSULTANT will
provide detour layout and traffic control strategies that complement the Alder Street
Intersection Project that is also scheduled for construction.
The CONSULTANT will design sewer main and service connections along the alley north of
Alder Street, between Palouse Street and 1st Avenue.
S:\DOCS\WW CITY\359‐135 ALLEY SEWER REPLACEMENT\AGREEMENT\AMENDMENT\EXHIBIT 1 ‐ SCOPE OF WORK.docx
The CONSULTANT will prepare construction plan sheets for CITY review. Plans will be prepared
at a scale of approximately 1 inch equals 20 feet. The plans will evolve with each submittal. The
following is the intended representation for the approximate design levels:
The 75 percent submittal will include detailed information with all potential work call outs.
The intent of the 75 percent submittal is concentrated on information being presented
accurately and completely. CADD cleanup work will still be evident. Two 11x17 hard copies
and a pdf electronic copy will be provided.
The final submittal will incorporate any remaining CITY comments and be a bid ready
document stamped and signed by the responsible Engineer.
The CITY will provide the CONSULTANT with available water and sewer plans and records to
□ Final Plan Set Including Approximately 10 Drawings
□ Cover with Vicinity Map, Index, and General Notes Sheets
The CONSULTANT will develop the project specifications based on the latest approved (2014)
Washington State Department of Transportation/American Public Works Association
(WSDOT/APWA) Standard Specifications for Road, Bridge, and Municipal Construction along
with General Special Provisions (GSP) and Amendments. CITY specifications and project specific
requirements will be incorporated as special provisions. Two hard copies and a pdf electronic
copy will be provided at each review phase.
□ Final Bid Ready Documents – Final Submittal
The CONSULTANT will develop an initial Opinion of Probable Costs based on preliminary design
quantities. Estimates will be compared to historic bid records of CITY projects and WSDOT
records. With each submittal, the quantities and unit bid costs will be updated as necessary. As
the project details evolve, the need for contingency will be reduced.
□ Preliminary Opinion of Probable Costs 75 Percent Submittal (15 Percent Contingency)
□ Final Engineer's Estimate Based on Final CITY Review (10 Percent Contingency)
S:\DOCS\WW CITY\359‐135 ALLEY SEWER REPLACEMENT\AGREEMENT\AMENDMENT\EXHIBIT 1 ‐ SCOPE OF WORK.docx
The CONSULTANT will provide quality assurance/quality control (QA/QC) for all design work in
accordance with the CONSULTANT's QA/QC standards. The CONSULTANT will provide senior
level design and construction personnel to review plan submittals and provide technical support.
The CONSULTANT will develop the bid documents based on the latest approved (2014)
WSDOT/APWA Standard Specifications for Road, Bridge, and Municipal Construction along with
GSPs and Amendments. CITY specifications and project specific requirements will be
incorporated as special provisions. Twenty final hard copies will be provided to the CITY for
distribution. One final electronic copy in pdf and dwg formats will be provided. Final
specifications will be provided in Word format.

text.b: TASK 4 ‐ BID AND AWARD PHASE SERVICES

page.text: The CITY will advertise the project and perform all construction administration services during the bid
and award phase. The CONSULTANT will provide construction and design experts who worked on the
project to be available to respond to Contractor questions during the bidding process. The CONSULTANT
will prepare and issue Addendums, attend one pre‐bid meeting, and provide assistance during bid
review, as requested by the CITY.
The CONSULTANT will provide complete construction management and administration services.
The CONSULTANT will act as the CITY's representative as provided in the Professional Services
Agreement. Construction management and administration duties will include the following:
1. Attend the Preconstruction Conference and provide meeting minutes.
2. Coordinate and provide oversight for all on‐site inspection services.
3. Receive, review, maintain, and approve all material submittals. Copies of all submittal
correspondence will be provided to the CITY.
S:\DOCS\WW CITY\359‐135 ALLEY SEWER REPLACEMENT\AGREEMENT\AMENDMENT\EXHIBIT 1 ‐ SCOPE OF WORK.docx
4. Receive, review, and determine the acceptability of any and all schedules provided by the
contractor. These may include the Progress Schedule, Schedule of Submittals, and Schedule
5. Track and issue a Weekly Statement of Working Days.
6. Review the Contractor's proposed monthly pay estimate and provide the pay estimate to
the CITY for review and approval.
7. Schedule and attend weekly on‐site construction meetings.
□ Copies of all Schedules Provided by the Contractor
□ Copies of all Written Communications with the Contractor
The CONSULTANT will provide part‐time on‐site construction inspection services. The
CONSULTANT's Construction Inspector will be the CONSULTANT's agent for the project and will
act as directed by, and under the supervision of the CONSULTANT. The Construction Inspector's
dealings in matters pertaining to the Contractor's work in progress shall in general be with the
CONSULTANT and the Contractor, keeping the CITY advised as necessary. The Construction
Inspector's dealings with subcontractors shall only be through, or with the full knowledge and
approval of, the Contractor. The Construction Inspector will generally communicate with the
CITY with the knowledge of, and under the direction of, the CONSULTANT. The CONSULTANT's
Construction Inspector responsibilities will include the following:
1. Serve as the CONSULTANT's liaison with the Contractor, working principally through
Contractor's superintendent, assist in providing information regarding the intent of the
Contract Documents. Assist the CONSULTANT in serving as the CITY's liaison with the
Contractor when the Contractor's operations affect the CITY's on‐site operations.
2. Assist in obtaining additional details or information from the CITY when required for proper
3. Report to the CONSULTANT when clarifications and interpretations of the Contract
Documents are needed. Transmit any clarifications and interpretations issued by the
4. Consider and evaluate Contractor suggestions for modifications to the Drawings or
Specifications and report such suggestions, together with the inspector's recommendations,
to the CONSULTANT. Transmit to Contractor in writing decisions as issued by the CONSULTANT.
S:\DOCS\WW CITY\359‐135 ALLEY SEWER REPLACEMENT\AGREEMENT\AMENDMENT\EXHIBIT 1 ‐ SCOPE OF WORK.docx
5. Conduct on‐site observation of the project to ensure all work is completed in accordance
with the Contract Documents. Advise the CONSULTANT of any special conditions encountered.
6. Coordinate with the CONSULTANT in advance of scheduled major inspections, tests, and
systems startups. Verify that appropriate CITY personnel are present and that adequate
records are kept for necessary testing.
7. Prepare a daily report recording all pertinent information such as the Contractor's hours on
the site, weather conditions, site visitors, daily activities and decisions, and data relative to
potential Change Orders, Field Orders, or changed conditions.
8. Immediately notify the CONSULTANT of any site accidents, emergencies, acts of God
endangering the work, or property damage.
9. Review the Contractor's pay estimates to ensure work being paid for is completed. Track
and process materials‐on‐hand in accordance with the Contract Documents.
□ Daily Tracking of Bid Item Quantities
The CONSULTANT shall coordinate all materials testing services. The materials testing work will
include scheduling and providing a qualified testing subconsultant for on‐site materials testing
and laboratory testing of base course, top course, concrete, and asphalt as required in the
Contract Documents at the frequency specified in the WSDOT Construction Manual.
1. The CONSULTANT will conduct a pre‐final inspection, complete substantial completion paperwork,
2. The CONSULTANT will conduct a final project inspection and prepare project closeout paperwork.
3. The CONSULTANT will prepare and submit construction Record Drawings from the red line drawings
S:\DOCS\WW CITY\359‐135 ALLEY SEWER REPLACEMENT\AGREEMENT\AMENDMENT\EXHIBIT 1 ‐ SCOPE OF WORK.docx
The following assumptions apply to this Scope of Work:
1. Preliminary and final plans for review will be produced on 11x17 sheets.
2. One set of AD‐ready PS&E plans will be provided on 11x17 sheets.
3. This project will be designed for construction under a single PS&E bid contract.
4. The CITY will pay all permit and advertisement fees for public meetings and bidding.
5. The CITY will provide aerial mapping and GIS data to supplement survey data.

page.text: S:\DOCS\WW CITY\359‐135 ALLEY SEWER REPLACEMENT\AGREEMENT\AMENDMENT\EXHIBIT 2 ‐ HOURLY FEE PROPOSAL
Re: Scope for Engineering Services – Walla Walla, WA Pipe Bursting Project: Risk Mitigation, Design Review,
The following scope and attached fee estimate are provided for engineering services for pipe bursting feasibility,
risk mitigation recommendations, plan sheet review and redlines, and method specification for the above
referenced project. We have also been asked to provide limited assistance during construction in the form of
trenchless related submittal and request for information review and response.
It is Staheli Trenchless Consultants’ (STC) understanding that we are to perform a study highlighting the feasibility
of upsizing an existing 6‐inch sewer to an 8‐inch sewer using the pipe bursting methodology. A site visit in
conjunction with a background review and review of the current pipeline’s condition will be performed to
ascertain an understanding of the site conditions and to identify project risks. The feasibility of employing the pipe
bursting methodology, including risk analysis and mitigation techniques, will be analyzed and described in a basis
of design technical memorandum (TM). As part of our scope, STC will provide pipe bursting calculations required
for design, produce a project specific pipe bursting specification, and review and make recommendations to
project plan and profile sheets generated by Anderson Perry. Furthermore, STC will provide 60% and 100% cost
estimates for the pipe bursting work and complete a final design review of the project and its contract documents.
The attached fee schedule is broken into project management, design services, and construction phase services.
Project management services include coordination with Anderson Perry, invoicing, and other administrative tasks.
Trenchless design services and construction phase services include the following:
Site visit to observe site conditions related to pipe bursting feasibility.
A review of background information and assessment of the existing pipeline’s condition
A basis of design TM documenting the feasibility analysis, identifying sources of construction risk, and
Pipe bursting plan and profile sheet review and recommendations (redlining).
Final design review of project and its contract documents.
Review and respond to trenchless related RFI’s and submittals.
I look forward to working with you on this project. Please contact me with any questions or comments.
Task 2 - Investigation and Background Review (Condition Assessment)
Task 3 - Basis of Design Technical Memorandum (Risk Identification and Mitigation)
Task 6 - Plan Sheet Review and Recommendations (Redlines)

5.D._Resolution_ Bid award to A & B Asphalt, Inc. for hot mix asphalt for $192,300 plus tax

The City of Walla Walla is seeking bids for hot mix asphalt. Bids are due by 1:00 p.m. on April 1, 2014, and are to be submitted to the City Clerk’s office, 15 N. 3rd Avenue (top floor), Walla Walla, Washington 99362. Bids shall be in a sealed envelo...
1. These instructions to bidders are a part of the specifications.

2. The City must be notified by 3:00 p.m. on Thursday, March 27, 2014, of any revisions the bidder suggests be made to the detailed specifications. Any changes, additions or deletions to the specifications by the City will be made by written addendum ...
3. Bids will be considered final at the time and date stated for opening bids. The City will not accept any changes for any reason.
4. Use of the enclosed bid proposal is required. Only bids submitted on the official bid proposal form will be considered.

5. Washington State Sales Tax WILL NOT be considered a part of the total bid. The successful bidder shall protect, defend, indemnify and hold the City, its agents, employees, officials and officers harmless from any damages, costs, or liability for an...

6. The bidder shall not discriminate against any client, employee, or applicant for employment and services on the grounds of race, creed, color, national origin, sex, marital status, age or presence of any sensory, mental, or physical handicap unless...

7. The bid shall be placed in a USEALEDU UENVELOPEU marked on the outside "2014 HOT MIX ASPHALT BID” and may be mailed or hand delivered to the City of Walla Walla City Clerk’s Office, 15 N. 3rd Avenue, Walla Walla, Washington 99362. All bids must be ...

8. The City of Walla Walla reserves the right to accept or reject any or all bids submitted. The City reserves the right to waive any irregularity in the bids to accept in whole or in part such bid or bids as may be deemed in the best interest of the...
9. Any additional information or questions concerning this call for Bids can be obtained by emailing George Bell at gbell@wallawallawa.gov.
